name: inferior good
description: An inferior good is a good that a person demands less of as income rises.  Standard examples of inferior goods include second-hand furniture and clothing and Spam.

clips.name: The Robbery
clips.description: Elaine is house sitting for Jerry.  Jerry explains the many flaws of his apartment.  George, a realtor, finds a new, bigger apartment for Jerry.  Elaine tries to get him to move so she can move into Jerry's old place.  “It's a dump,” she says, “but it's a step up for me.”

tags.name: inferior good
tags.description: An inferior good is a good that a person demands less of as income rises.  Standard examples of inferior goods include second-hand furniture and clothing and Spam.

tags.name: normal good
tags.description: A normal good is a good that a person will purchase more of as income rises. Most goods are normal goods.

source.title: Seinfeld
source.description: Seinfeld ran for nine seasons on NBC and became famous as a “show about nothing.” Basically, the show allows viewers to follow the antics of Jerry, George, Elaine, and Kramer as they move through their daily lives, often encountering interesting people or dealing with special circumstances. It is the simplicity of Seinfeld that makes it so appropriate for use in economics courses. Using these clips (as well as clips from other television shows or movies) makes economic concepts come alive, making them more real for students. Ultimately, students will start seeing economics everywhere – in other TV shows, in popular music, and most importantly, in their own lives.
